body: I thought that `windows.h` was needed for more than just `HWND`? Just a few lines lower down a comment implies that we also need its declarations relating to WGL.
@tombsar I tried that change on my end for [raylib](https://github.com/raysan5/raylib) and everything seems to work fine.

Ok, it looks like the only other thing needed in `glfw3native.h` itself is `HGLRC`, and that's conditional on `GLFW_EXPOSE_NATIVE_WGL` which you might not be using in raylib?.

I think we would have to continue to include `windows.h` (maybe with `WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN`?) in the case that `GLFW_EXPOSE_NATIVE_WGL` is enabled, but I like your suggestion otherwise.

Oh! Yes! My mistake! You're right! I'm not using `GLFW_EXPOSE_NATIVE_WGL` so, don't have that problem.

`WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN` doesn't work for me, still exposes too many dup symbols.

I investigated a bit and `HGLRC`, it's most probably a `void *`, actually `glut.h` just defines `typedef void *HGLRC;`... but digging on `windows.h`, `windef.h` defines `DECLARE_HANDLE(HGLRC);` macro (also used for `DECLARE_HANDLE(HWND);`) that is defined in `winnt.h` as:
```c
typedef PVOID HANDLE;
#define DECLARE_HANDLE(name) typedef HANDLE name
```
Same file also defines `typedef void *PVOID;`.

In conclusion, most probably, those handlers are always `void *`.

About inclusion order of `glfw3native.h`, some security check could be added to avoid redefinition but, yes, in that case `windows.h` must be included before `glfw3native.h`.

Also, trying to get **Cocoa native window handler** (also defined as `void *`):
```c
    #if defined(__APPLE__)
        #include <unistd.h>             // Required for: usleep()
        #include <objc/message.h>       // Required for: objc_msgsend(), sel_registerName()
        
        #define GLFW_EXPOSE_NATIVE_COCOA
        #define GLFW_EXPOSE_NATIVE_NSGL
        #include <GLFW/glfw3native.h>   // Required for: glfwGetCocoaWindow(), glfwGetNSGLContext()
    #endif
```
I get the following compilation warning and error:
```
In file included from /Users/travis/build/raysan5/raylib/src/external/glfw/include/GLFW/glfw3.h:195:
/System/Library/Frameworks/OpenGL.framework/Headers/gl.h:5:2: warning: gl.h and gl3.h are both included. Compiler will not invoke errors if using removed OpenGL functionality. [-W#warnings]
#warning gl.h and gl3.h are both included.  Compiler will not invoke errors if using removed OpenGL functionality.
 ^
In file included from /Users/travis/build/raysan5/raylib/src/core.c:171:
/Users/travis/build/raysan5/raylib/src/external/glfw/include/GLFW/glfw3native.h:104:17: error: typedef redefinition with different types ('void *' vs 'struct objc_object *')
  typedef void* id;
                ^
/usr/include/objc/objc.h:46:29: note: previous definition is here
typedef struct objc_object *id;
```

The warning implies that you have something in your code that includes "gl3.h" (maybe an OpenGL loader library?). Defining `GLFW_INCLUDE_NONE` before including glfw.h is the intended way to disable that second inclusion, which should fix the warning.

The error arises because you include `objc/message.h`, which in turn includes `objc.h`, and defines `id` properly. I believe the error could be avoided if we guard glfw3native.h's dummy typedef with `#if !OBJC_TYPES_DEFINED`. That's really a separate issue/PR (as it affects MacOS only), although the principle is the same as we were discussing for Windows.

Thanks! Effectively `gl.h` was already included by a secondary library (`glad.h`).

Also tried the guard around the typedef for MacOS but it keeps breaking... should I open a second related issue?

> One other concern is how the header will interact with user code that wants to include `windows.h` for other reasons. If the user includes `glfw3native.h` before including `windows.h`, us having defined `HWND` already will probably cause errors, and visa versa.

Yup. If you're fetching platform specific handles then presumably you're going to pass them to a platform specific API at some point and that code will need to be namespace compatible with that platform.

> @elmindreda is this a change you would want to make? I don't use native access at all; maybe users are relying on it to include the whole of windows.h?

If I got to do `glfw3native.h` again I'd remove the inclusion of platform specific headers, so that user code gets to choose whether to include them or define the necessary bits itself like above.

As it is, the inclusion of these headers is a documented part of `glfw3native.h` and I won't change it until 4.0.
The `Windows.h` header defined `_WINDOWS_` so you can always guard against redefinitions if others are including that header by doing an `ifdef` against that symbol.
With 05f6c13d119ea2662c97527d2421fb4cffd3dbfc there is now support for the `GLFW_NATIVE_INCLUDE_NONE` macro, which disables the inclusion of platform-specific headers by `glfw3native.h`.
